children.name: to move to a less important job
downgrade
children.definition: verb giáng chức; giáng cấp; hạ cấp

children.name: to reduce someone or something to a lower rank or position, or to make something less important or less valued
examples: _My job's been downgradedtothat of ordinary editor.
_We mustn't let management downgrade the importance of safety at work.

children.name: to lower someone or something in rank or position
examples: _The captain was demoted (tosergeant) for failing to fulfil his duties.

children.name: to move to a more important job
promote
children.definition: to give someone who works in an organization a more important job than the one they had before:
examples: ▪ The company promotes women and minorities whenever possible.
be promoted
▪ Did you hear that David’s been promoted?
promote somebody to something
▪ Shula was promoted to head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals in 1991.
promoteverbRAISE thăng chức; thăng cấp
[ T often passive ]to raise someone to a higher or more important position or rank
_If I'm not promoted within the next two years, I'm going to change jobs.
_She's just been promotedtosenior sales rep.
_If Coventry City win this match, they'll be promotedtothe Premier League.

children.name: make sb sth U
children.definition: make somebody something  to move someone to another job, usually a better, more important one within the same organization:
examples: đưa ai lên làm ...
▪ No-one thought they would make him manager so soon after joining the company.
▪ He’s been made Head of Security at the Chicago National Bank.

children.name: promotion
children.definition: when someone is given a more important job in an organization:
examples: ▪ Civil service tests determine promotion in government jobs.
▪ What are my chances of promotion if I stay here?
get a promotion
▪ She got a promotion last year.
promotionnounRAISE sự thăng tiến; sự thăng chức
[ C or U ] when someone is raised to a higher or more important position or rank
_ Steveget/Was Stevegiventhe promotion he wanted?
_The job offers excellent promotionprospects.
_Fiorentina's win againstPalermolast night has considerably increased their chances of promotion this season.

children.name: advancement
children.definition: when someone moves up to a better, more important job:
examples: ▪ Many people are forced to move from one city to another in search of better jobs or career advancement.

children.name: climb up the ladder U
children.definition: move/go/climb up the ladderalsowork your way up the ladder  to gradually become more and more successful, and get better, more important jobs:
examples: ▪ Feldman started working for the company at age 18, and slowly worked his way up the ladder.
▪ Education is vital to help these children to move up the career ladder.

children.name: upgrade
children.definition: to move someone up in a job, especially by making the job they are already doing more important, and by paying them more for it:
examples: ▪ The women demanded that their work be upgraded.

children.name: upgrade somebody to something
examples: ▪ After the inspector’s visit all temporary workers were upgraded to permanent status.

children.name: to be moved up from a low level position in an organization to a higher one
examples: _He rose through the ranks to become a General.
_He joined the company in 1998 and has been rising through the ranks ever since.

children.name: to move a company or its people to another place
post
examples: to send someone to a particular place to work
_He's been postedtoPakistanfor six months._Guards were postedatall the doors

children.name: move
examples: move somebody (from something) to something
chuyển ai đó (từ cái gì đó) tới cái gì đó
▪ The Education Department is considering moving 500 full-time staff to Runcorn.
move something (from something) to something
chuyển cái gì đó (từ cái gì đó) tới cái gì đó
▪ The company says it will move its distribution center to Chicago early next year.

children.name: transfer
children.definition: to move someone from one place to another, especially to another job, department, or office within the same organization:
examples: dời, chuyển, dọn
transfer to
dời, chuyển, dọn tới
▪ Davidson transferred to another department last October.
transfer somebody (from something) to something
dời, chuyển, dọn ai đó (từ cái gì đó) tới cái gì đó
▪ One option would be to transfer Struthers from London to New York.
▪ Harding has been transferred to Albany prison, where he will complete his sentence.
transferverb-rr- chuyển sang/di chuyển
[ I or T usually + adverb or preposition ]to change to a different job, team, place of work, etc., or to make someone do this
_After a year he transferredtoUniversity College,Dublin.
_Some very high-profile British players have transferredtoclubs abroad.
_He threatened to give up football if his club didn't transfer him (= sell him to another team) .

children.name: relocate
children.definition: topermanentlymove part or all of a company to another place, especially when this brings financial advantages:
examples: di chuyển ( công ty đến nơi mới có lợi thế hơn về tài chính )
▪ If rents continue to rise, many local businesses may decide to relocate.
relocate to/in
di chuyển tới/vào
▪ The federal government is offering attractive tax breaks to corporations that relocate in areas of high unemployment.
relocate something to/in something
di chuyển cái gì đó tới/vào cái gì đó
▪ We’re relocating our educational software division to North Carolina.
relocation/ˌriːləʊˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]sự di chuyển, tái định cư
▪ Salary and other benefits are excellent and include a company car and help with relocation.
relocation expenses
chi phí di chuyển
▪ Does the company pay relocation expenses?

children.name: shunt
children.definition: to move someone from one job to another, especially alessimportant one:
examples: chuyển
shunt somebody from/to/into something
chuyển ai đó từ/tới/vào trong cái gì đó
▪ I’m sick of being shunted from one department to another.
▪ The company’s solution to dealing with incompetent staff seems to be to shunt them into clerical jobs.

children.name: transfer
examples: when something or someone moves or is moved from one place, position, etc. toanother
_the transfer of information
_Black's transfertoan Italian football club came as a shock toCoventrysupporters.
_The official transferofownership will take a few days to complete.
transfer/ˈtrænsfɜːʳ/ [countable noun]sự dời chỗ
▪ She’s put in for a transfer asked to be transferred to the Los Angeles office.
